awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Digital Device to Improve the Safety of Extraventricular and Lumbar Cerebral Spinal Fluid Drainage
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a reusable management system and disposable tubing that may cut current costs while improving the standard of care by reducing patient discomfort, reducing medical errors associated with extraventricular and lumbar drain use, and reducing nursing management time. Extraventricular and lumbar drain systems are used in approximately 60,000 patients annually in the US with a market of $1.04B in 2021. The research team has performed discovery interviews with neurosurgeons and ICU nurses, which have validated the need for customizable drainage control and improved management efficiency. The postoperative management of extraventricular and lumbar drains is primarily a nursing responsibility, consisting of hourly checks and manual releveling whenever patients change position. The use of conventional extraventricular drains add significantly to a nurse’s workload, especially since they are mandated to ensure close supervision with a nurse-to-patient ratio of 1:2. To improve the state-of-the-art, this technology takes continuous pressure measurements, compensates for patient movement to minimize discomfort and harm to patients from over or underdrainage, provides far more customizable control for patient optimization, and uses a much less expensive disposable.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an external cerebrospinal fluid drainage system that provides customizable drainage control for neurosurgeons, requires less intervention by nurses, and makes cerebrospinal fluid drainage safer for patients. The device in development is used to drain cerebrospinal fluid from the brain via an extraventricular drain or from the spine via a lumbar drain, and to aid in the diagnosis and treatment of elevated intracranial pressure. State-of-the art drainage systems connect to an existing ventricular or lumbar catheter that has been placed by a neurosurgeon to drain cerebrospinal fluid and measure pressure using a hospital’s existing standard pressure transducer. This technology’s disposable tubing line connects to existing brain and spine catheters and pressure transducers using industry standard Luer locks. The technology and its disposable parts are never placed inside humans. The sterile disposable tubing is manually secured to the technology’s controller system externally. The closed drainage system is not disrupted, limiting infection risk to the patient.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE MEDICAL COLLEGE OF WISCONSIN, INC.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Medical College of Wisconsin, Inc

por.por_cntn:
This research project involves the development of an external cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) drainage system that provides customizable drainage control for neurosurgeons, requires less intervention by ICU nurses, and makes CSF drainage safer for patients. The device in development, is used to drain CSF from the brain via an extraventricular drain (EVD) or from the spine via a lumbar drain (LD), and to aid in the diagnosis and treatment of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), to reduce the accumulation blood and other debris that could negatively impact outcomes, to reduce the chances of CSF leak, to potentially improve blood flow in thoracic aortic aneurysm surgery, and to serve as a platform for infusing medications to treat conditions such as infections, cancers, vasospasm etc. State-of-the-art drainage systems connect to an existing ventricular or lumbar catheter that has been placed by a neurosurgeon to drain CSF and measure ICP using a hospital’s existing standard pressure transducer. Our innovation uses a simpler and less expensive disposable tubing line that connects to existing brain and spine catheters and pressure transducers using industry standard Luer locks. Our reusable management system and disposable tubing aim to cut current costs in half while improving the standard of care by reducing patient discomfort, reducing medical errors associated with EVD and LD use, and reducing nursing management time. Our disposable parts are never placed inside humans and are manually secured to our controller system externally.  The closed drainage system is not disrupted for drainage and infusions, limiting infection risk to the patient.  The device also allows the care team to control pressure and flow in ways that are needed in clinical practice but that are unavailable today.  Furthermore, management with our system results in precision drainage that is unmatched by any existing CSF technology.

 

EVD and LD systems are used in approximately 60,000 patients annually in the US with a market of $1.04B in 2021. The research team has performed 140+ discovery interviews with neurosurgeons and ICU nurses, purchasing agents, and manufacturers which have validated the need for customizable drainage control and improved management efficiency as well simplicity and cost control. They provided insights for potential use-cases and benefits of the device. The postoperative management of EVD and LDs is primarily a nursing responsibility, consisting of hourly checks and manual releveling whenever patients change position. The use of conventional EVDs add significantly to a nurse’s workload, especially since they are mandated to ensure close supervision with a nurse-to-patient ratio of at least 1:2. To improve the state-of-the-art, our device takes continuous ICP measurements, compensates for patient movement to minimize discomfort and harm to patients from over or underdrainage, provides far more customizable control for patient optimization, and uses a much less expensive disposable. These characteristics make it attractive to hospitals that have neurosurgical capabilities, of which there are 572 in the US. The safety features present in the invention, such as the balloon suction detector, are unique and not found in current state-of-the-art systems.  Our technology has a patent filed in 2021 that has been assigned to our university’s tech transfer office. 

 

After the I-Corps interviews, we pivoted on the design of our device and now have a completed UI/UX on a 7” touch screen, we have an IV pole mounted box that contains the precision pump device mechanism, and we’ve interfaced with multiple sensors that achieve the safety elements called out in the interviews.  Furthermore, we’ve worked with an FDA consultant to determine that the 510K process is our pathway to FDA approval and we also began to identify and fulfill the requirements for the various sections of our application.  Additionally, we’ve identified a contract manufacturer that can help with manufacturing and regulatory filings for both our controller and disposable tubing. 

 


Last Modified: 09/03/2024
Modified by: Joshua E Medow
